poem:
Panzanella Secrets

stale bread soaked,
in ripe tomato's pulse—
summer's treasure

transformed from scraps
to a lover's feast,
in juice and sunlit basil,
the old world sings

a simplicity,
that swells my heart—
in every humble bite,
the earth's own art.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Why stale bread is your secret salad weapon – recipe | Waste not Panzanella is a zero-waste dish from Tuscany and Umbria that’s usually made by soaking stale bread in water to soften it. Here, to increase the flavour, I’ve also used tomato juice to soften the bread further, a trick I picked up from Tito Bergamashi, the former head chef of Petersham Nurseries in London, with whom I worked on launching the banquets at". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
